node.title: How to define the physical parameters associated with variables
node.bodyText:
Hi, Prof
I would like to ask how to define variable-related physical parameters in the input file.
For example, I want to define a density that is related to the temperature variable. Can I define the property parameters of this type through the Function in the input file without modifying the code.
Thanks.

Hello
Typically for a quantity that is dependent on another variable, we use the Materials and Material Properties system.
Please see the documentation for that system here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Materials/index.html
Guillaume

Thank you, Guillaume
Your advice is of great help to me.
I remember using a method that didn't need to change the code, just set the input file, but I seem to have forgotten it.

there are parsed material expressions you may use:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ParsedMaterial.html
and for fluid properties, it's easier to work with the fluid properties module to set all these quantities
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/fluid_properties/index.html

Thank you, Guillaume
Thank you for your help.

node.title: Preconditioner and Linear solver
node.bodyText:
Hi,
At first, I have some questions about the preconditioner and linear solver.


In some simple problems, we can use LU/iLU and ksp gmres/bcgs to solve linear equations. Unfortunately, LU could not solve complex problems due to expensive resource consumption, especially with more than 100000 DOFs. Therefore we must use other preconditioners such as asm or bjacobi to solve linear equations. Frustratingly, it often happens that the system of linear equations does not converge so that the whole problem cannot be solved. But I found that we can change some options such as -sub_pc_factor_levels and -pc_factor_shift_type to help solve linear equations. Are there any descriptions of these options like -sub_pc_factor_levels on any website?


I am always confused by diverged problems such as DIVERGED_FNORM_NAN and DIVERGED_LINEAR_SEARCH, etc.  Are there any descriptions of these diverged problems like DIVERGED_FNORM_NAN and DIVERGED_LINEAR_SEARCH, etc on any website?


Besides, I have some questions about the nonlinear solver.


MOOSE's default nonlinear solve method is PJFNK. In my opinion, if the jacobian matrix is could be made by hand or automatic difference, the NEWTON method is more effective and fast to solve the FEM problems. I'm not sure I'm right about the opinion.


In nonlinear solve progress, Is linear_search necessary? Are there any descriptions of these line_search methods on any website?


Thanks.

Hello
1)
See petsc documentation for more info. All we have on solver options is here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/executioners/Steady.html
2)
These are errors codes from Petsc that we are passing to the user. You may look at their documentation. They generally mean the nonlinear solver is failing, which either means there's a bug in the Jacobian or better initialization would help.
You should check the Jacobian with the Jacobian analyzer
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/development/analyze_jacobian.html
Nonlinear solver:
1)
See this documentation
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/systems/NonlinearSystem.html
Since we often use the Jacobian for the preconditioning in PJFNK, the memory consumption is similar to Newton's. But if we did not, the memory consumption would be much smaller for PJFNK than Newton's, hence the default.



All we have on line searches are this page. The petsc manual is a better reference since we're just importing a petsc tool here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/LineSearches/
I turn off the line search for ALL my modeling. I've never had it improve things. But this is physics and numerics dependent.
Guillaume

Thank you, Mr. Guillaume
Your advice is of great help to me.
According to my experience, the NEWTON method is the most efficient and effective method for solving nonlinear equations. PJFNK method is too slow.
According to Krylov, I think there should be a way to tweak the JFNK method so that the residual drops even more, possibly at the cost of slower computation

What I want to know is whether there is such an adjustable interface to tune JFNK methods.
Thanks
This is also going to live on the petsc side I'm afraid. See their documentation / their forum

node.title: Can MOOSE support silp boundary condition like as no-penetration boundary condition
node.bodyText:
Dear,
I want to simulate some non-sticky problems. So I need to set no-penetration boundary condition. What I'm wondering is that can MOOSE support silp boundary condition like as no-penetration boundary condition.
Looking forward to your reply, thank you.

Hello
Please have a look at the contact module documentation, especially the frictionless models
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/contact/
Guillaume

Thanks for your reply. I think I may not have described my problem clearly.
In fact, I want to simulate  non-sticky flow through navier-stokes module. So I need to set no-penetration boundary condition as shown below.

Then I want to add wall function BC and no-penetration BC to k-ω or k-ε model. What I'm wondering is that can I set a no-penetration as a NodalBC or  IntegratedBC?
Looking forward to your reply, thank you.

Hello
No flux is the default boundary condition, so no-slip no-penetration is the default.
So for FE you could leave it as is.
Guillaume

Dear Prof.
Thank you for your reply.I think what I described may have led you to misunderstand.
In other words.I want to add a no penetration bc for momentum equation rather than a no flux or no slip bc.
As you mentioned above, no slip is /vec u=0, and no flux is /nabla u /cdot /vec n=/nabla v  /cdot /vec n = /nabla w  /cdot /vec n=0.
Here I write no penetration bc is /vec u /cdot /vec n = 0. These are different, so I want to consult you if moose have no penetration bc.
Looking forward toyour reply. Thank you for your reply and help again.

Dear Prof.
Please allow me to add a little description as shown below.

the last one is no diffusive flux.
no-penetration is the same as no advective flux
If you want you can add a boundary condition that does nothing. Simply not executing advection kernels on the boundary nodes is enough to have 0 advection there

Dear Prof.
Thank you for your reply.
If I understand you correctly, you mean to introduce the terms of advective flux by integration by parts to advective term. Here's how I did it.

If this method is used, the outlet must be given a advection boundary condition. Unfortunately, I found this method to be less robust than the current method. And I think that's probably why by default MOOSE don't integrate by parts for advection terms.
Therefore I'm wondering whether there are other robust methods to achieve no penetration BC on MOOSE.
Looking forward toyour reply. Thank you for your reply and help again.

In INS-FE both approaches have been implemented. I dont know that a conclusion was made as to which approach is more robust. But we moved to finite volume for most of the Navier Stokes work, where we do integrate that term over faces (eg basically an integration by part)

Thank you,
This is worth studying. As far as I know, the COMSOL turbulence module has these functions.

node.title: Can MOOSE get a normal vectors and the height of the first grid on "Nodal BC"
node.bodyText:
Dear,
I want to add a Dirichlet BC to an advection-diffusion problem, but the node values need to be calculated by the normal vector and the height of the first grid.
In fact, IntegratedBC can help me calculate the normal vectors through _current_side_elem[_qp]->normal(). Unfortunately, I need to set up a DirichletBC. The NodalBC have no function to compute normal vectors. Even though I add _normals(_assembly.normals()) in my class. It still could not  compute normal vectors correctly.
tips:

The height of the first grid on "Nodal BC"

normal vectors


Looking forward to your reply.

I assume this is FE not FV. Either way, the node normals aren't well defined. You'll need to do some sort of averaging over the connected element edges. There is a NodalNormals aux kernel that you could use as a starting point.

see this page of documentation for example
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/AddNodalNormalsAction.html

Thank you,
Your advice is very helpful to me.

node.title: RANS k-ε model
node.bodyText:
Hi Everyone,

First of all, thank you to all the workers in Idaho. MOOSE has really helped me a lot.
And I learned from Workshop Slides that a coarse regularized k-epsilon model will be added soon. What I want to know is whether the model is based on FEM? And how soon can it be added?
Besides, I feel that no new model has been added to the FEM Navier-Stokes module for a long time. I don't know whether the module will be updated in the future.
Thank you for your time.

Hello
The model will be based on finite volume.
It ll be added this summer.
At INL we are no longer expanding the finite element Navier Stokes capability. For our applications it has proved unsatisfactory and the finite volume work is our focus right now. We are still accepting and would gladly review contributions from the community on the finite element side.
Guillaume

Hello,
It has proved unsatisfactory.
Does this mean that the finite element research in CFD is not in-depth enough, resulting in the poor robustness of this method? Or because of the program structure, it may be unexpectedly difficult for finite element CFD to continue to develop based on MOOSE.
If it is the first reason, I think I will continue to do this and provide open source code to the community in the future.
If it's the second reason, it's really a shame, because I think MOOSE is the most beautiful of the finite element frameworks so far
Thank you for your time.

MOOSE didnt preclude implementing advanced schemes for finite element CFD. The unsatisfactory parts were the lack of local conservation in our CFEM implementation (DG schemes can be conservative), the sharps peaks near flow corners, and the ambiguity at corners of fixed velocity inlets with no-slip walls (what value do you pick for the corner node?)
I dont mean to discourage your research or adding much-needed turbulence models to our FEM CFD.
Some of the developments we are working on, such as segregated solver capabilities in MOOSE, will also be applicable to finite element, benefitting both implementation's performance

Hello, Guillaume
Segregated solver capabilities in MOOSE. That is an exciting capability. How soon will this capability be implemented in MOOSE?
within a year most likely.

Thank you, Mr. Guillaume
Look forward to more features, thanks to the Idaho staff.
By the way. Where can I get some of the new features for Navier-Stokes? Although the code may not have passed the rigorous testing in Idaho, I want to get a taste of some of these features.
Or some other finite element program for Navier-Stokes that was previously developed but not posted to Github, even though it's not completely finished.
Thanks.

node.title: Adjust the judgment condition of nonlinear convergence
node.bodyText:
Hello，
In some non-steady-state problems, some time steps may have less nonlinear residuals fall, while others may have more.  How should I give consideration to these two situations?

In other words, I want to make the nl_rel_tol that is difficult to converge less strict, and the nl_rel_tol that is easy to converge smaller. How can I set different nl_rel_tol at the same time
Thank you for your time.

Hello
We currently dont support variable convergence criteria.
You can sort of hack it by setting min and max number of non linear iterations, but there's no first class support
The right way would be to rework the Executioner and the NLSystem classes to support functions for these convergence criteria
Guillaume

I think it might be more beneficial to figure out why the nonlinear solve is performing so poorly. Is your Jacobian inaccurate? You can test this with -snes_test_jacobian. Are you taking too large of timesteps such that your initial guess is too far from the root such that Newton's method performs poorly?

also if you're debugging issues a particular timestep, it helps to create a checkpoint right before that time step (just add checkpoint=true to [Outputs]), then restart there to examine the issues.
It could also be scaling issues. This page has a few potential issues listed
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html

Thank you, Mr. Guillaume and Mr. lindsayad
Your advice is of great help to me.
I think maybe my problem is too complex, there are many problems like grid size, quality, and so on. Turbulence models may also be needed to help with convergence.
Thanks again

node.title: coupling of TH and poroelastic mechanics (HM)
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I meet a poroelastic problem of coupled natural convection (TH) and poroelastic mechanics (HM).
This benchmark is simplified based on this work using Comsol (https://www.essoar.org/pdfjs/10.1002/essoar.10508352.1).
Problem information:
Aim: To study the effect of the mechanic (M) on the buoyancy-driven convection (TH)
Geometry: x and y is (0, 5500) m; z is (-5500, 0) m; Fig. 1.
Blocks: basement (impermeable) and fault (permeable)
BCs: (1) Top surface: fixed 293.15 K temperature and 10^5 Pa porepressure; (2) Bottom surface: NeummannBC of temperature is 0.1 W/m^2, disp_x,y,z =0;
ICs: (1) temperature: '293.15-z0.03' ; (2) porepressure: '100000-10009.81*z'
EOS: same to the above paper. Water density is the function of temperature and porepressure. Water viscosity is the function of temperature.
permeability and porosity evolution: no.
automatic_scaling = true
Couplings: TH (i.e. buoyancy-driven convection) and HM (i.e. poroelastic) couplings. No thermal expansion and volume expansion.
Forces: only body force (gravity).
Other detailed properties are shown in input files.
My work:

buoyancy-driven convection (TH).

The result is Ok.

HM poroelastic mechanics

I test some examples from (https://github.com/ajacquey/golem/tree/master/test/tests/HM). The result is also fine.

coupling of buoyancy-driven convection (TH) and poroelastic mechanics (HM)

(1) Steady simulation;
kernels:

pure heat conduction (T kernel)
pure porepressure diffusion (H)
body force kernel (my app)
PoroMechanicsCoupling
Tensor Mechanics Master Action System (M kernels).
EOS: constant water density 1000 (kg/m3)and viscosity (1e-3 Pa.s).

(2) Transient simulation:

the kernels in steady simulation
transient temperature and pore pressure kernels
HM coupling kernel (my app, _biot[_qp] * _vol_strain_rate[_qp] * _test[_i][_qp])

a. It uses the output results (temperature, pore pressure, displacements (using or ignoring)) of steady simulation as the initial values of Transient simulation.
b. Moreover, I learn the examples about setting 'ComputeEigenstrainFromInitialStress' (regarding body force as initial stress) from https://github.com/idaholab/falcon/blob/devel/test/tests/THM_injection/thm_steady.i and https://groups.google.com/g/moose-users/c/ceMFbx9CgiE. To be honest, I am not sure whether should I regarding body force as initial stress.
c. The application of the stresses is applied progressively by setting the body gravity increases from 0.01 to 9.81 in 10 years.
However, all my previous Transient simulations output very terrible convergence information (as follows) even at first time step t=1s.
My request: Could you please give me some tips on my problem? Thanks a lot!
good steady simulations information

...

Hello
A few questions:

is the gravity ramp up consistent between the steady and transient solutions? Or is the pressure field initialization for the real gravity in the transient?
does it converge without the coupling term, with just the addition of the time derivatives
did you implement the Jacobian term for your custom coupling kernel? Or are you using automatic differentiation?

Guillaume

node.title: Compiling and Testing Moose
node.bodyText: I am not able to find the closing button.

what's the output of mamba list ?
and the diagnostic script in moose/scripts ?

It looks like the compilation was terminated by external means.
You may be running out of memory during the build. Seeing those diagnostics would really help (what @GiudGiud asked for). You can create a diagnostic log by performing the following:
cd moose/scripts
./diagnostics.sh > my_log.log
and attaching the file created my_log.log.
Closing this, interface not letting me select an empty message as the answer

node.title: Unsuccessful convergence of a simple steady first order convection problem.
node.bodyText:
Hi, I am just getting started to use moose and I want to first solve a very simple steady, first order problem.
So here is a thing, I want to solve enthalpy of this equation, where W is set to be constant so i can put it out of the partial differential term.

Then if I offer the boundary condition at the inlet, it can be easily solved using FDM and we can get the outlet value. However, in my moose application, if the boundary condition is set to the inlet 'left', the solve will not converge, while setting it to the outlet 'right', the calculation will proceed normally.
But what's the difference? I cannot figure it out, can anybody help me with that? I'll appreciate it so much.
Below is my input file here.
[Mesh]
    type = GeneratedMesh
    dim = 1
    nx = 20
    xmax = 1.0
    xmin = 0
[]

[Variables]
    [H]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    []
[]

[Kernels]
    [ker1]
        type = GradTerm
        variable = H
	velocity = '1.0 1.0 1.0'
    []
    [source1]
        type = ValTerm
        variable = H
    []
[]

[BCs]
    [bc1]
        type = DirichletBC
        variable = H
        value = 1133820.0
        boundary = "left"  
# If I set the boundary to "right", the solve will proceed normally  
    []
[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
  [H]
    type = NodalValueSampler
    variable = H
    #boundary = 'bottom'
    block = 0
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end' 
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    sort_by = x
  []
[]

[Problem]
    type = FEProblem
    coord_type = XYZ
    rz_coord_axis = X
[]

[Executioner]
    type = Steady
    solve_type = 'NEWTON'
    automatic_scaling = true
[]

[Outputs]
    exodus = true
    csv = true
[]

Hello
So this is an advection problem. The information sees to be flowing in the positive X direction ( I m guessing based on the parameters, you have to look at how you implemented this )  in this 1D mesh.
So the boundary condition has to be set at the inlet, which should be left not right.
since this is actually the non-converging case, I would guess there is an issue in GradTerm
btw you dont need this parameter in XYZ
    rz_coord_axis = X

also you should initialize W. The initial guess of 0 might be difficult to solve from
Guillaume

Thank you so much, I have revised my code, and tried to use JFNK method instead. The calculation has finally converged. Perhaps the JFNK method is better in performance than the Newton method after all.
The fact that Newton is poor almost definitely implies that the Jacobian in your code is wrong.  Otherwise, Newton would be far superior.

But I cannot find anything wrong in my code now, could you please have a look at them for me? THX!
GradTerm.h
ValTerm.h
GradTerm.C
ValTerm.C
input.i

In your GradTerm.C you have _test[_qp][_i] which is incorrect. It should be _test[_i][_qp] instead.
I agree with @WilkAndy
I don't think the convergence issue is related to your BC.
You have a pure advection problem, which cannot be solved by FEM without stabilization.

Perhaps this is getting off-topic here, but i don't totally agree with @hugary1995 about advection: i believe FEM can solve advection without using stabilization, but in most cases (mesh sizes, timestep sizes) the errors are unacceptable.
Advection problems are also quite sensitive to correct boundary conditions.  Eg, it's quite easy to accidentally create a model which is trying to extract "stuff" (fluid, heat, etc) from a boundary when there actually isn't any "stuff" there to extract.  In that case MOOSE (and any decent numerical solver) will not converge because there truly isn't any solution.

Interesting... I thought you get instabilities from the inf-sup condition for advection-dominated advection-diffusion problem, which as you said, can be solved without stabilization (subject to acceptable errors).
But it is different for pure advection problems. I haven't seen anyone solving it without stabilization IIRC. Let's say we look at the equation in the OP, there is no transient term, no artificial viscosity, no diffusion, no stabilization -- just advection and a constant source. Isn't the matrix singular?
Ugh no, what was I taking about... there's a Dirichlet BC. So as long as he doesn't use -pc_type lu he should be fine.
And you are right about the BC as well.

I think your comments raise an important point, @hugary1995  .   That is, @89018580 , are you sure that this is the problem you actually want to solve?  The solution is just H = linear function of x.  Do you also want some time dependence, @89018580  ?

In fact I want to solve a more comlex problem where there are some time dependences. But as I am just getting started to use MOOSE, I think perhaps it's better to solve a simplified steaty problem as my first step.
In the original  steady conservation equations, the time derivatives are removed, as there is no diffusion and viscosity, the velocity W can be seen as the constant.

The equations can be seen as coupling of variables P and H, in which H can be solved alone（rho is set as linear interpolation of H）. So I tried to solve H first and H should be a linear function of x. I thought it should be easy but I ran into the convergence problem.
So does that mean advection problems are not suitable to be solved with NEWTON?

node.title: How to add compressive stress on dendrite growth surface？
node.bodyText:
I want to study the growth of dendrites by applying stress on the surface. How to add compressive stress on dendrite growth surface？
As shown in the picture below：

Zhang_2021_J._Electrochem._Soc._168_090522.pdf
I studied some examples. Is this an example of increasing compressive stress on the surface？https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/combined/examples/phase_field-mechanics/interface_stress.i

@dschwen @recuero who can I tag on dendrites?
Are Zijian Hong and Venkatasubramanian Viswanathan on github and active on the MOOSE repo?
@SudiptaBiswas?
@biaogxb I don't think we have the exact example you are looking for. This can be done with the phase-field mechanics approach. You will have to implement the free energy components though.
